block.p: INTERNATIONAL 3-26

Bricks Sustaining India's Poor As India undergoes an unprecedented construction boom, more and more Indians are giving up farming for the meager wages of brick making. But the success of the brick business is as much a portrait of a growing industry as it is a testament to the dismal state of the Indian peasantry.

Lebanon Closes In on Militants Heavy shelling and gunfire continued for the second day at the Nahr al Bared refugee camp, as the Lebanese Army intensified its offensive against the Fatah al Islam militia. Three soldiers were killed and 15 were wounded, the army reported.

U.S. Strikes Targets in Somalia American forces struck inside Somalia, bombarding a mountainous area where suspected militants were hiding out, Somali officials said. It was the third known American strike in Somalia this year.

Bombs Damage Bridge in Iraq Bomb blasts severely damaged a bridge linking a highway from Baghdad with the northern city of Kirkuk, the police and witnesses said, heightening tensions between Arabs and Kurds and forcing traffic to detour through some of the most dangerous areas of Diyala Province.

Militant Leader Killed in Gaza A field commander from the Palestinian militant faction Islamic Jihad was killed in an Israeli air attack on his vehicle in Khan Yunis, in the southern Gaza Strip, army officials and Islamic Jihad said.
NATIONAL 28-35

The Fate of a Child Soldier In a legal battle with implications for the growing numbers of child soldiers worldwide, the United States wants to prosecute an alleged Qaeda operative for killing a soldier in Afghanistan.
Immigration Splits G.O.P. President Bush's advocacy of an immigration overhaul plan is creating a backlash among the radio hosts, commentators and congressional allies who usually support him. 1

Censured Doctors at Work An analysis of Minnesota state records found more than 100 doctors who have been sanctioned by a medical board but later paid to do research on a drug or speak to other doctors about its uses.
Same-Sex Conjugal Visits Gay and lesbian prisoners in California will be allowed overnight visits with their partners under a new prison policy.
NEW YORK/REGION 37-41

Plot to Bomb Kennedy Airport Four men, including a onetime airport cargo handler and a former member of the Guyanese Parliament, were charged with plotting to blow up fuel tanks, terminal buildings and the web of fuel lines running beneath Kennedy International Airport. Three of the four suspects were taken into custody in Trinidad and in Brooklyn, while the fourth man was still at large. 37
